D1.title: Designing a New Course in the AI Era
D1.narrative: You are preparing a new course at Soka University of America. Students already use AI for brainstorming, translation, and writing. Which stance will guide your design?

resources.label: Soka University Mission
resources.why: Ground course goals in SUA’s mission.

P1.title: Setting the Boundary
P1.narrative: You draft your new course policy: "AI-generated text is not permitted on any assignments." You tell students that true learning requires struggle — "The effort to express one's own ideas builds understanding." Students nod, though one asks privately if translation tools count.

resources.label: Turnitin (2024) — AI Writing Detection Report
resources.why: False positives and faculty trust challenges.

P2A.title: The Translation Question
P2A.narrative: A multilingual student confides: "I only use AI to translate readings so I can understand class discussion." You reaffirm your rule: each student should rely on their own effort to develop language skills. Participation drops, and you sense growing distance.

resources.label: NASEM (2023) — Ethics of AI in Education

P3A.title: The Enforcement Semester
P3A.narrative: You implement AI detection software and restate strict consequences. Midterm, a false flag occurs — a student accused of AI use insists on innocence. The process consumes hours of investigation. Students stop visiting office hours; compliance rises, curiosity drops.

resources.label: Inside Higher Ed (2024) — False AI Accusations

P4.title: Outcome: Integrity Preserved, Dialogue Lost?
P4.narrative: Your records show near-perfect compliance. But course evaluations describe your class as "serious, but tense." You reflect: integrity was upheld — yet engagement and empathy weakened. Has control achieved the learning it sought to protect?

resources.label: Harvard GSE — Teaching for Trust in the Age of AI

B1.title: Designing the New Course
B1.narrative: You're drafting a syllabus for a new interdisciplinary seminar at Soka University of America. You know that students are already using AI for translation, brainstorming, and writing support. Rather than ban it, you design a short unit on "Responsible AI Use." Students will practice writing with and without AI, comparing their processes and reflecting on what they learn.

resources.label: Soka University Mission Statement
resources.why: Frames AI use as a question of global citizenship.

resources.label: UNESCO (2023) — Guidance for GenAI in Education

B2A.title: Ethical AI Workshops
B2A.narrative: Week three. Students bring examples of AI output alongside their own writing. They identify what AI captures — and what it misses. Discussion turns lively: "How do we know when AI's help becomes substitution?" You realize they're not just learning writing — they're learning judgment.

resources.label: EDUCAUSE Review (2024) — Teaching AI Literacy & Ethics
NASEM (2023) — Ethics of AI in Education

B3A.title: Refining the Policy
B3A.narrative: Together, the class revises its "AI Use Agreement." Students agree to cite AI assistance, reflect on their process, and take responsibility for final ideas. You notice improved confidence in weaker writers and fewer integrity concerns. Still, updating and clarifying the policy each semester takes time. Some colleagues worry: "Won't this gray area confuse students?"

resources.label: Soka CTLE — Sample Syllabus Language on Ethical AI Use

B4.title: Outcome: Ethical Clarity Through Dialogue
B4.narrative: By term's end, students submit reflective essays describing how AI shaped their thinking. Most express gratitude for being trusted to decide responsibly. A few still wish for simpler rules, but many highlight new awareness: "I learned not just what AI can do — but what I can do with it." You sense the course has fostered something deeper than compliance: wisdom.

resources.label: Harvard GSE — Reflective Judgment in AI‑Era Classrooms
Soka University Mission Statement
resources.why: Connects ethical literacy to contributive lives.

E1.title: Rethinking the Assignment
E1.narrative: You sit at your desk drafting the syllabus for your new interdisciplinary course. You know students already use AI for brainstorming and translation. Instead of policing that reality, you wonder: "What if I invited AI use as part of the process itself?" You rewrite a major paper assignment into an "AI-Reflection Portfolio," where students must document prompts, evaluate AI output, and annotate what they learned about thinking itself.

resources.label: Soka University Mission Statement
resources.why: Links creative redesign to wisdom and global citizenship.

E2A.title: First Iteration
E2A.narrative: Students experiment with AI during early drafts. Some produce nuanced reflections; others hand in work too dependent on the tool. In discussion, you model critical use: showing how to question AI's assumptions. The room fills with energy — half excitement, half uncertainty. One student says, "I've never thought so much about how I write."

resources.label: Harvard GSE (2024) — Metacognitive Awareness
resources.why: How reflection on process deepens learning.

E3A.title: The Assessment Challenge
E3A.narrative: Grading portfolios takes longer than expected. You realize authentic work requires new evaluation criteria — growth, insight, and self-reflection now matter more than grammar or format. A peer asks, "Isn't this subjective?" You reply, "Maybe — but so is learning." By mid-semester, students begin referencing AI critically in discussions about ethics, bias, and creativity.

resources.label: Soka CTLE — Reflective Portfolios & Learning Journals

E4.title: Outcome: Innovation and Depth
E4.narrative: At semester's end, students present reflective projects titled "What I Learned From My AI Mistakes." Their work is messy, honest, and profound. Some still rely too much on the tool, but most articulate a clearer sense of authorship. You feel both exhausted and inspired. When you present at a CTLE roundtable, a colleague says, "This feels like the future of Soka education — humanistic, creative, responsible."

resources.label: Soka University Mission Statement
resources.why: Connects authentic learning to wisdom, courage, and compassion.

C1.title: Opening the Dialogue
C1.narrative: You invite students to co‑draft an AI Reflection Charter for transparency, curiosity, and respect.

resources.label: EDUCAUSE Review (2024) — Culture of AI Dialogue

C2A.title: Shared Experimentation
C2A.narrative: Students keep AI learning logs and discuss when AI helps or hinders thinking; critique deepens.

C3A.title: Faculty Learning Cluster
C3A.narrative: Colleagues join a learning cluster. You share anonymized reflections; assessment norms are discussed.

choices.label: Move toward formal policy (switch to Balanced)

C4.title: Outcome: Dialogue Becomes the Curriculum
C4.narrative: Students feel trusted and responsible. Model spreads; time demands remain a constraint.

resources.label: Inside Higher Ed (2025) — Dialogue as Curriculum

R1.title: Teaching for Value Creation in the AI Era
R1.narrative: Each approach surfaced trade‑offs: integrity, creativity, equity, trust, workload. Compare what you protected, what you risked, and what you discovered — and align next steps with SUA’s mission to foster global citizens who live contributive lives.
